work.title: De sideribus
work.author: Ps. Priscianus
work.incipit: Ad boreae partes Arctoi uertuntur et Anguis
work.explicit: Hinc sequitur Pistrix simul Eridanique fluenta.
work.bibl: Anthologia Latina, I, 2, p. 139, no. 679.

work.title: Aratus Latinus
work.incipit: Ostensionem quoque de quibus uidentur oportet fieri
work.explicit: in annum umquam reliquimus continentem in coelo signum.
work.bibl: Maass, pp. 102-306.

work.title: Anonymus Sangallensis
work.incipit: Herodius dicit helicem licaonis fuisse filiam
work.explicit: absides eius ultima in capricorno est.

work.title: Aratea
work.author: Cicero
work.incipit: E quibus hunc subter possis cognoscere fultum
work.explicit: Hanc autem totam properant depellere Pisces.
work.bibl: Cicéron, Les Aratea. Ed. by Victor Buescu. Paris: Les Belles Lettres, 1941.
Marcus Tullius Cicero. Aratea. Fragments Poétiques. Ed. by Jean Soubiran. Les belles lettres, 1972.
Online PHI Latin Texts

work.title: Arati ea quae videntur
work.note: Part from Aratus Latinus and Revised Aratus Latinus
work.incipit: Ostensionem quoque de quibus videntur oportet fieri
work.explicit: ut nihil te latere possit, quorum ab eo dicta sunt.
work.bibl: Maass, pp. 102-126.

work.title: Astronomica
work.author: Manilius
work.incipit: Carmine divinas artes et conscia fati
work.explicit: totus et accenso mundus flagraret Olympo.

work.summary: 17 verses on the Roman calendar its months, weeks and days.
work.incipit: Bissena mensium uertigine uoluitur annis
work.explicit: personas idus decurrens atque kalendas.
work.bibl: Ed. in Baker and Lapidge 1995, p. 384.

work.title: The Collatio Alexandri et Dindimi
work.summary: Consists of five fictive letters (three by Alexander, two answers from Dindimus, king of the Brahmans of India. Was probably originally written in Greek, although no Greek text has survived. According to Ross the two other Alexander texts, the Epitome and the Epistola, were intended to appear together, while the Collatio was added to them later. The Collatio was regarded as a useful tract on the ascetic like and so makes a frequent appearance in collection of moral and religious character (p. 128). Judging by the growing number of manuscripts from the twelfth century onwards shows that the interest in the texts was growing presenting the Indians as good pagans par excellence in the later Middle Ages (p. 278).
work.incipit: Sepe ad aures meas fando peruenit rationem uitae
work.explicit: quia donata repudias, aut invidiae, quod a meliore praestantur.
work.bibl: Pritchard, T. "The Collatio Alexandri et Dindimi: A Revised Text," Classica et Mediaevalia 46 (): 255-283 (not using this manuscript).
Steinmann, M. "Die Collatio Alexandri et Dindimi – eine annotierte Arbeitsbibliographie," Göttinger Forum für Altertumswissenschaft 4 (2001) 51-84
Cary, G. "A Note on the Medieval History of the Collatio Alexandri cum Dindimo," Classica et Mediaevalia, 15 (1954): 124-9.
Ross, D. J. A. "A Check-list of MSS of Three Alexander Texts: The Julius Valerius Epitome, the Epistola ad Aristotelem and the Collatio cum Dindimo" Scriptorium 10 (1956): 127-132.

work.title: Commentary in Plato's Timeus

work.incipit: Timaeus Platonis et a ueteris difficilis habitus atque existimatus est ad intellegendum

Timaeus a Calcidio translatus commentarioque instructus in societatem operis coniuncto. Edited by Jan H. Waszink. London: The Warburg Insitute, 1962.

work.title: Commentarium in Ciceronis somnium Scipionis

work.incipit: Inter Platonis et Ciceronis libros quos de re publica uterque constituit
work.explicit: quo universa philosophiae continetur integritas.
work.bibl: Ambrosii Theodosii Macrobii Commentarii in somnium Scipionis Macrobius, Ambrosius Theodosius. Leipzig: Teubner, 1963.
Corpus corporum

work.title: De architectura
work.author: Vitruvius
work.incipit: Cum divina tua mens et numen, imperator Caesar, imperio potiretur orbis terrarum invictaque virtute
work.explicit: uti totum corpus omnia architecturae membra in decem voluminibus haberet explicata.
work.bibl: Vitruvius: Ten Books on Architecture. Translated by Ingrid D. Rowland. Cambridge University Press, 1999.
Vitruvius. De L’architecture. Edited by Jean Soubiran. Second edition. Paris: Les belles lettres, 2003.
Online text in LacusCurtius.

work.title: De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercirii
work.author: Martianus Capella
work.incipit: Tu quem psallentem thalamis, quem matre Camena progenitum perhibent, copula sacra deum
work.explicit: secute nugis, nate ignosce lectitans.
work.bibl: Martianus Capella. De nuptiis philologiae et mercurii. Edited by James Willis. Leipzig: Teubner, 1983.

Martianus Capella. Martianus Capella and the Seven Liberal Arts. Vol. 2, The Marriage of Philology and Mercury. Translated by William H. Stahl and Richard Johnson. New York: COlumbia University Press, 1977.

work.title: De nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii. Book VIII. De astronomia

work.explicit: importat radius Solis affulgens, qui eos percutiens aut in sublime
work.bibl: Martianus Capella. De nuptiis philologiae et mercurii. Edited by James Willis. Leipzig: Teubner, 1983.

Martianus Capella. Martianus Capella and the Seven Liberal Arts. Vol. 2, The Marriage of Philology and Mercury. Translated by William H. Stahl and Richard Johnson. New York: COlumbia University Press, 1977.

work.title: De signis (interpolated version)
work.incipit: Quinam tamen multa dicunt et alii aliter narrasse celum diuersis proferentes uocabulis sed ipse magis axe continetur quam se continui indemetipso reuoluitur. Habet autem undique inponderata per medium terre in circuitum celi equalem deductum

work.title: Horologium

work.note: short opening and six sections each addressing two months (having equal shadow values)
work.incipit: Quos cursu solis iungunt sua tempora menses
work.explicit: Humani ignaris monstrat quas corporis umbra.
work.incipit: Linea quae Iani prima est pariterque Decembris
work.explicit: Hinc centro torrens ternos sibi sexta retentat

work.title: In quo signo versetur mars
work.incipit: In quo signo uersetur Mars: annis ab initio mundi per senarium divisis et annorum hunc numerum excedentium mensibus
work.explicit: Sin autem prima partitio duodenario concludatur, in Virgine memoratum semper inueniri planetam.
work.bibl: David Juste, "Neither Observation nor Astronomical Tables: An Alternative Way of Computing the Planetary Longitudes in the Early Western Middle Ages," in Studies in the History of the Exact Sciences in Honour of David Pingree, Leiden-Boston, MA 2004, pp. 181-222, with editioin in the appendix (pp. 216-217).
Entry in Mirabile.
work.note: The work offers a method to calculate the longitude of the five planets without the need of observation or manipulation of astronomical tables. Since one knew the position of the planets during Creation, one needed just to calculate the time elapsed since Creation and do the neccessary multiplication.

work.title: De positione et cursu septem planetarum
work.incipit: Inter caelum et terram certis discreta spatiis semptem sidera pendent
work.explicit: Dein morata in coitu solis biduo cum tardissime a tricesima luce ad easdem vices exit.
work.note: Excerpt from Pliny, Historia naturalis, Lib. II.
work.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce, and Gerd Graßhoff. "Planetary Diagrams for Roman Astronomy in Medieval Europe, Ca. 800-1500." Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 94, no. 3 (2004): I-158, here 22-27.
Borst, Schriften, Vol. 3, pp. 1260-63.

work.title: De intervallis earum
work.incipit: Intervalla eorum a terra multi indagare temptarunt
work.explicit: Ita septem tonis effici quam diapason armoniam vocant.
work.note: Excerpt from Pliny, Historia naturalis, Lib. II.
work.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce, and Gerd Graßhoff. "Planetary Diagrams for Roman Astronomy in Medieval Europe, Ca. 800-1500." Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 94, no. 3 (2004): I-158, here 27-30.
Borst, Schriften, Vol. 3, pp. 1263-65.

work.title: De absidibus earum
work.incipit: Tres autem quas supras solem diximus sitas
work.explicit: sicut in rotis radios ut subiecta figura demonstrat.
work.note: Excerpt from Pliny, Historia naturalis, Lib. II.
work.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce, and Gerd Graßhoff. "Planetary Diagrams for Roman Astronomy in Medieval Europe, Ca. 800-1500." Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 94, no. 3 (2004): I-158, here 30-35.
Borst, Schriften, Vol. 3, pp. 1265-69.

work.title: De cursu earum per zodiacum circulum
work.incipit: Cur autem magnitudines suas et colores mutent
work.explicit: Sed inter omnia haec sidera martis maxime inobservabilis est cursus.
work.note: Excerpt from Pliny, Historia naturalis, Lib. II.
work.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce, and Gerd Graßhoff. "Planetary Diagrams for Roman Astronomy in Medieval Europe, Ca. 800-1500." Transactions of the American Philosophical Society 94, no. 3 (2004): I-158, here 35-40.
Borst, Schriften, Vol. 3, pp. 1270-1273.

work.title: Scholia Basileensia
work.incipit: Quaeritur quare ab Ioue coepit et non a musis ut Homerus
work.explicit: Effusum est lac et facta est circuli albi species.
work.bibl: Dell’Era, Antonio. "Gli Scholia Basileensia a Germanico," in Atti Della Accademia Nazionale Dei Lincei: Memorie, Classe di Scienze morali, storiche e filologiche. Ser. VIII, vol. XXIII. Romе, 1979, pp. 301-379.

work.title: Scholia Strozziana
work.incipit: Caelum circulis V distinguitur, quorum II extremi maxime frigide, australi humilimus et aquilonius excelsissimus
work.explicit: Immo et ceteri pisces, sed hi tantum apparent, quia exiliunt, ceteri in imo gurgitis descendunt.
work.bibl: Dell’Era, Antonio. "Una miscellanea astronomica medievale: gli "Scholia Strozziana" a germanico," in Atti Della Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei: Memorie, Classe di Scienze morali, storiche e filologiche. Ser. VIII, vol. XXIII. Romе, 1979, pp. 147-267.
